text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chorizo steamed clams that's
right when we think of steamy and
comforting bowls of food during the cold
winter months we usually associate that
with long slow simmering that takes
hours but as you're about to see with
the Spanish inspired steamed clam dish
that's not always the case
these clams are not only easy and
delicious they're very fast to make plus
they're theresa involved which is always
a good thing so let's go ahead and get
started with the start of the show the
clams so what I have here is three
pounds of Little Neck clams which have
been thoroughly rinsed to remove any
sand and by the way just because I'm
using Little Neck doesn't mean you have
to I bet you could also do this with
cherry stone or razor clams or Manila
clams you are the ramp all of this clam
call so feel free to be a libertarian
and as long as you're not hurting
anybody else use any variety you want
which also includes mussels and then
besides the clams of course we're going
to need some chorizo sausage which come
already cooked in these links and the
rule of thumb here is we want to use one
ounce of chorizo for each pound of clams
that is considered the perfect chorizo
ratio or as we refer to it in the
business the chore ratio and since this
link is 6 ounces we'll just cut it in
half which will give us our three ounces
sorry I should have warned you we were
going to do map and then split that down
the middle and then each of those pieces
in half and then we'll simply turn it
and slice it up into I don't know
eighth inch quarter inch slices you know
the drill
pick a size and stick with it and by the
way if you don't think you can find
trees oh but you have access to another
kind of flavorful spicy sausage can you
use it well yes yes you can so we'll go
ahead and we'll slice up our chorizo as
shown and then besides the clams and our
Spanish sausage the only other things
we're going to need are some finely
diced onions some freshly chopped
parsley and some finely minced garlic
and that is pretty much it
oh except we're also going to need some
white wine something nice something
drinkable but don't waste your money
getting a really nice one all I'm using
is a nice $8 bottle of Sauvignon Blanc
which has a screw top remember screw top
doesn't mean bad screw top means cheap
and then once we have all our mise
implies together which I'm not sure what
the Spanish word for that is we can head
over to the stove to get this Fiesta
start
so what we'll do is we'll place the soup
pot on medium heat into which we've
added a splash of olive oil and we will
toss in our diced onions and cook those
stirring for about three or four minutes
or until they just start to turn
translucent and usually we throw a pinch
of salt in here but be careful all right
the sausage is highly seasoned plus
clams are kind of naturally salty so I
usually wait to the end to see if I need
to add any salt but anyway like I said
we're going to click those stirring
until they just start to turn
translucent at which point we will toss
in our sliced chorizo and we will cook
that stirring for about three minutes
and since reaso is already cooked we're
not doing it for that reason we're
basically doing it to render some of
that beautifully flavorful fat out so
we'll cook that sausage for a few
minutes until it just starts to take on
a little bit of color and as I mentioned
some of the fat starts to render out and
once that's happened we'll go ahead and
toss in our garlic and only cook that
for one minute
as usual we don't a brown the garlic so
we'll cook that garlic stirring for
about 60 seconds at which point we will
jump in our white wine and then do two
very important things we will raise our
heat to high because we got to bring
this up to a boil and then just as
importantly we got to make sure we have
the cover handy because what's going to
happen as soon as this comes up to a
boil we're going to carefully add our
clams in preferably without splashing
ourselves and then as soon as we Nestle
those in as evenly as we can we will
quickly cover this and let it cook on
high heat for about seven minutes or
until the clams open up and while some
people like to remove the lid and give
these a stir a couple times I don't you
lose all the steam so what I prefer is
just grab a couple towels and give it
the whole shake of sheikha and during
the seven minutes I'll do that maybe two
or three times and if everything goes
according to plan about seven minutes
later those clams will have opened up
and you should be looking at something
very similar to this and yes it looks
great and you want to eat but it's not
quite done yet
what we're going to do is we'll turn off

only going to take a few seconds we are
ready to dish up and I didn't show it
but right here is where you would taste
to see if your broth has enough salt and
then once all that's mixed together and
you're happy with how it tastes
you're ready to serve this up so we'll
transfer some clams in
hopefully a hopple and of course we're
going to ladle over lots of that
amazingly flavorful broth as well as
maybe a little more parsley and then to
finish this off of course we need

amazing liquid and I'm not saying you
have to serve this with grilled bread
I'm just saying you absolutely should
and by the way I cleverly planned this
so you still have a half bottle of wine

of which I'm going to do that right now
and there's just something about that
